descriptions.content:
Contrary to normal practice in the European languages and in Chinese, Tibetan inserts a pause (when one is required) after, not before, the conjunction. In fact, the particle དང་ is often followed by a punctuation mark, the རྐྱང་ཤད་, which indicates a pause.

  • པཱ་ལགས་དང་། ཨ་ཁུ་དང་། ཨ་ནེ། “Father, uncle, and aunt....”

To reproduce the Tibetan rhythm, we would have to say: “the father and… the uncle and… the aunt.”

The conjunction དང་ is distributive with respect to case and number. This means that the noun group that precedes it has no number or case marker: these markers appear only once, at the end of the whole group. Thus in the following example, the plural marker appears only once.

  • ཨ་མ་དང་སྤུ་གུ་ཚོ། “The mother and the children...” (Tibetan would not say: *ཨ་མ་ཚོ་དང་སྤུ་གུ་ཚོ།)

In the following examples, the case marker appears only once:

  • བུ་དང་བུ་མོ་ཚོར་ལག་རྟགས་སྤྲད་པ་རེད། “(They) gave presents to the boys and (to the) girls.”
  • ཚེ་རིང་དང་བློ་བཟང་གིས་ཨ་རག་བཏུངས་སོང་། “Tsering and Lopzang drank some alcohol.”
